Expectation1: Design and develop technical solutions to meet project requirements
Situation1: Stakeholders expect a working prototype soon to secure internal approval
Expectation2: Officiate at life cycle events such as weddings, bar/bat mitzvahs, and funerals.
Situation2: A congregant has just passed away and the family needs him to officiate the funeral service very soon.
Story: I stared at my phone, the email from the project manager still open on my laptop. The prototype demo was scheduled for tomorrow, and the team was counting on me to finalize the design tonight. Without a working prototype, the stakeholders might pull the plug, and months of work would be lost. My mind raced with technical details—circuit diagrams, code snippets, last-minute tweaks. Then my phone buzzed again. It was Miriam from the synagogue. Her voice trembled as she told me that her father had passed away. The family needed me to officiate the funeral service as soon as possible, to guide them through their grief and honor their loved one. I could hear the pain in her voice, the expectation that I would be there for them, as their rabbi. My heart ached, torn between the urgent needs of my team and the sacred responsibility to my community. I sat at my desk, paralyzed, feeling the weight of both worlds pressing in, unsure how I could possibly meet the demands of both.
